Award.AwardTitle: REU Site: Climate Science Research at The Pennsylvania State University
Award.AbstractNarration: This proposal supports the training of 30 undergraduate students in climate science research. The proposal is for three years. Ten students each year during the summer will have a choice of conducting research in multiple disciplines, such as atmospheric science, oceanography, terrestrial ecology, chemistry and biogeochemistry. The overall objective is to attract a diverse group of students to climate science research by simulating the graduate research environment as closely as possible. The program is a complete immersion in the research process complemented with weekly activities to enhance students' professional development through workshops on basic research skills and seminars on science communication, ethics, graduate school, and career opportunities. Students will report their research in the form of a peer-reviewed journal article and a talk in the style of a scientific conference or a video for a general audience.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Understanding the inner workings of the climate system and how it responds to human activity is not only intellectually challenging but of great societal importance. Decisions are being made and will continue to be made about a wide array of climate-sensitive policies concerning energy, the economy,
water resources, and land use. Climate scientists are an essential part of the decision-making process because they provide the information about potential future changes in the environment and what their impacts are likely to be under given scenarios of greenhouse gas emissions and given strategies for
adapting to the predicted environmental changes.

The Research Experiences for Undergraduates (REU) Program in Climate Science at The Pennsylvania University helps to meet the need for climate scientists by providing students an immersive research experience with some of the world's top climate scientists. The program recruited 37 students during the summers of 2016, 2017, and 2018 (12–13 students per year). Each student participated in a single 10-week program. A student was typically mentored by an individual faculty member with assistance from graduate students, post-doctoral scholars, and other faculty members. The overwhelming majority of the students' time was spent conducting research.

Because climate science is highly interdisciplinary, original research was conducted on a wide variety of topics. Research projects covered atmospheric transport of greenhouse gases, methane emissions, wildfire dynamics, aerosol formation, computer modeling, ocean–atmosphere interaction, impact of air quality on health, soil moisture, ocean circulation, cloud physics, biosphere–atmosphere interaction, tropical cyclones, atmospheric turbulence, paleoclimate, hydrology, coastal flooding, communication of climate information, agricultural productivity, salt-marshes, atmospheric circulation, and estuarine chemistry.

Weekly professional development activities lasting 1–2 hours complemented the
research. These activities typically included seminars on climate science and
policy, information about graduate school, workshops on science communication,
and panels about science careers.

Students had many accomplishments during and after the program. Each student wrote a paper about their research in the form of a peer-reviewed scientific journal article and gave a presentation at a symposium during the last week of the program. The overwhelming majority (33 of 37) of the students presented their research at one or more international, national, or state science conferences during the following academic year. Five students won awards or received recognition for their conference presentations.

Additional positive outcomes from the REU program were revealed by surveys and tracking of students after they left the program. Surveys conducted at the beginning and end of each summer program indicated that students gained confidence in their research skills and had their high expectations of mentors met. Tracking of students determined that students are progressing well in their careers. 27 students went on to graduate school and 15 are currently employed, 2 in academia, 9 in the private sector (mostly at environmental or energy consulting firms), and 4 in government. Even if students do not go on to careers in climate science, they have gained an appreciation for scientific research and a better understanding of one of the most pressing global issues of our time.
